com.avaya.csta.tonecollection

Interface ToneCollectionServices


  • public interface ToneCollectionServices
    Used to buffer the tones that are received by a device and report them when the specified retrieval criteria are met.

    Start DTMF tone collection on a device with the startToneCollection method . Then, each time a DTMF tone is detected, it is put in the buffer and the tones in the buffer are checked to see if the retrieval criteria are met. If the buffer is full, the oldest DTMF in the buffer is overwritten.

    Add a listener on a device with addToneCollectionListener method.There is no more than one ToneCollectionListener per device at a time.

    Use flushBuffer method to flush the buffer during collection. Flushing cleans out the buffer and clears the retrieval criteria.

    Set the retrieval criteria with setToneRetrievalCriteria method. The retrieval criteria may be one or more of the following:

    1. a specified tone has been detected.
    2. a specified number of tones has been detected.
    3. a specified initial timeout or interdigit timeout has elapsed.

    The first one to occur causes the buffered tones to be retrieved and the retrieval criteria to be cleared. Even though the retrieval criteria are cleared, the connector server continues buffering detected tones. If you want to retrieve tones, call setToneRetrievalCriteria method again.

    When you no longer wish to be notified of the retrieved tones, remove the listener on the device with removeToneCollectionListener method.

    Tone Collection continues until the stopToneCollection method is used to terminate the collection.

    The retrieved tones are reported via the TonesRetrievedEvent. The cause of the event may be any of the following:

    • FLUSHCHARRECEIVED - when the tone specified in the retrieval criteria is received.
    • CHARCOUNTRECEIVED - when the number of tones specified in the retrieval criteria is received.
    • TIMEOUT - when the amount of time, initialTimeout or interdigitTimeout specified the retrieval criteria has elapsed.
    • BUFFERFLUSHED - when the flushBuffer method is called.

    The buffer size is configurable in the cmapi-user-configuration.properties file. The property is called 

     com.avaya.mvcs.tone.ToneCollectionServices.buffer.size
    The default size is 32. You can configure the buffer size based on the retrival criteria in your application.

    Prerequisites Before attempting to use ToneCollectionServices, do the following:

    1. Obtain a ToneCollectionServices object by using ServiceProvider.
      2.  ToneCollectionServices toneCollectionSvcs =
   (ToneCollectionServices)servProv.getService(com.avaya.csta.tonecollection.ToneCollectionServices.class.getName());
    2. Implement a ToneCollectionListener to specify what to do in case of tones being retrieved. Add this listener using the MonitoringServices.addToneCollectionListener method.

    Clean Up After you are finished using this service, do the following:

    1. Remove any listener you added for a device using the MonitoringServices.removeToneCollectionListener method.
    2. Stop tone collection using stopToneCollection method.
    Since:
    Communication Manager API 2.1
    Version:
    $Revision: 1.4 $
    Author:
    AVAYA, Inc.

    • Method Detail

      • startToneCollection

        ToneCollectionStartResponse startToneCollection(ToneCollectionStart request)
                                         throws CstaException
        Used to start DTMF tone collection for a specific device. See the ToneCollectionStart request for more information.

        Here is an example of how to start tone collection: 

         ToneCollectionStart request= new ToneCollectionStart();
 CallObject object = new CallObject();
 object.setCall(connection)     // or object.setDevice(deviceID);
 request.setObject(object);
 ToneCollectionStartResponse response =
                toneCollServ.startToneCollection(request);

        Parameters:
        request - a ToneCollectionStart service request specifying the device to collect DTMF digits
        Returns:
        a ToneCollectionStartResponse message indicating the request has been received and appears valid
        Throws:
        InvalidParameterValueException - if request is null
        InvalidConnectionIDException - if the ConnectionID/DeviceID of this request is null
        OperationException - if ToneCollectionServices has already been started for the device. You may resolve the problem by stopping tone collection using the stopToneCollection method, and then restarting tone collection.
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • stopToneCollection

        ToneCollectionStopResponse stopToneCollection(ToneCollectionStop request)
                                       throws CstaException
        Used to stop DTMF tone Collection on a device. See the ToneCollectionStop request for more information.

        Here is an example of how to stop tone collection: 

         ToneCollectionStop request= new ToneCollectionStop();
 CallObject object = new CallObject();
 object.setDevice(deviceID) // or object.setCall(connection);
 request.setObject(object);
 ToneCollectionStopResponse response =
                toneCollServ.stopToneCollection(request);

        Parameters:
        request - a ToneCollectionStop service request specifying the device to stop to collect DTMF digits for
        Returns:
        a ToneCollectionStopResponse message indicating the request has been received and appears valid
        Throws:
        InvalidParameterValueException - if request is null
        InvalidConnectionIDException - if the ConnectionID/DeviceID of this request is null
        OperationException - if internal error occurs
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • flushBuffer

        ToneCollectionFlushBufferResponse flushBuffer(ToneCollectionFlushBuffer request)
                                       throws CstaException
        Used to flush the buffer. See the ToneCollectionFlushBuffer request for more information.

        Here is an example of how to setup a ToneCollectionFlushBuffer request: 

         ToneCollectionFlushBuffer request= new ToneCollectionFlushBuffer ();
 CallObject object = new CallObject();
 object.setCall(connection)     // or object.setDevice(deviceID);
 request.setObject(object);
 request.setSendEvent(Boolean.FALSE);
 request.setClearCriteria(Boolean.FALSE);
 ToneCollectionFlushBufferResponse response =
        toneCollServ.toneCollectionFlushBuffer(request);

        Parameters:
        request - a ToneCollectionFlushBuffer service request specifying the device whose buffer should be flushed, if a TonesRetrievedEvent should be sent and the retrival criteria should be cleared.
        Returns:
        a ToneCollectionStopResponse message indicating the request has been received and appears valid
        Throws:
        InvalidParameterValueException - if request is null
        InvalidConnectionIDException - if the ConnectionID/DeviceID of this request is null
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • addToneCollectionListener

        void addToneCollectionListener(DeviceID device,
                               ToneCollectionListener listener)
                        throws CstaException
        Deprecated. Use MonitoringServices.addToneCollectionListener instead.
        Adds a listener to monitor the specified device for tone collection events.

        Java listeners are used to implement the CSTA concept called monitoring.

        When an event occurs, the corresponding listener callback is called. A default callback is provided by ToneCollectionAdapter for each possible event. The default callbacks do nothing. If you want to act upon events, you can customize the events' callbacks for your application in either of the following ways:

        • Provide an implementation of every callback method in the ToneCollectionListener interface with a class that implements ToneCollectionListener.
        • Provide an implementation of a subset of callback methods with a class that extends ToneCollectionAdapter.

        Multiple listeners can be added to a device, then the listeners will be notified of events on that device; the corresponding callback will be called on the listener that has been added.

        Parameters:
        device - the device to which the ToneCollectionListener is added.
        listener - the listener being applied to the device. The listener may be an implementation of the ToneCollectionListener interface or an extension of ToneCollectionAdapter.
        Throws:
        InvalidParameterValueException - if device ID or listener is null
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • removeToneCollectionListener

        void removeToneCollectionListener(DeviceID device,
                                  ToneCollectionListener listener)
                           throws CstaException
        Deprecated. Use MonitoringServices.removeToneCollectionListener instead.
        Removes a previously specified tone collection listener.

        If no listener is on the device or the specified listener is not one that was previously added or the listener is null, then no exception is thrown and no function is performed.

        Parameters:
        device - the device whose ToneCollectionListener is to be removed
        listener - the listener being removed from the device.
        Throws:
        InvalidParameterValueException - if device ID is null
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • setToneRetrievalCriteria

        ToneRetrievalCriteriaResponse setToneRetrievalCriteria(ToneRetrievalCriteria request)
                                                throws CstaException
        Used to specify the criteria to retrieve tones from the buffer. See the ToneRetrievalCriteria request for more information.

        Here is an example of how to setup a ToneRetrievalCriteria request with all types of criteria set: 

         ToneRetrievalCriteria request= new ToneRetrievalCriteria ();
 CallObject object = new CallObject();
 object.setCall(connection)     // or object.setDevice(deviceID);;
 request.setObject(object);
 request.setFlushCharacter("#");
 request.setNumberOfTones(new Integer(8));
 request.setInitialTimeout(new Long(20000));
 request.setInterdigitTimeout(new Long(10000));
 ToneRetrievalCriteriaResponse response =
                toneCollServ.setToneRetrievalCriteria(request);

        Parameters:
        request - a ToneRetrievalCriteria service request specifying retrieval criteria for a device.
        Returns:
        a ToneRetrievalCriteriaResponse message indicating the request has been received and appears valid
        Throws:
        InvalidParameterValueException - if request is null, or no retrieval criterion is set, or neither initialTimeout nor interdigitTimeout are not in the request, or numberOfTones or initialTimeout or interdigitTimeout is less than or equal to zero.
        InvalidConnectionIDException - if the ConnectionID/DeviceID of this request is null
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs
